qas.question: What is Liberia's highest judicial authority?
How many members are in the Supreme court?
Who is the head of the supreme court?
How are members chosen for the court?

answers.text: Members are nominated to the court by the president and are confirmed by the Senate

qas.question: How long do members of the supreme court serve?
What is the highest judicial authority in Anglo-America?
What is a blend of common law and supreme law?

plausible_answers.text: within the rural areas of the country

qas.question: Where does customary law still exist?
How many members is the magistrate court made up of?
To what age are Senators guaranteed salary?

context: Liberia's highest judicial authority is the <a0_0><b5_0>Supreme Court<b5_0/><a0_0/>, made up of <a1_0><b8_0>five<a1_0/> members<b8_0/> and headed by <a2_0>the Chief Justice of Liberia<a2_0/>. <a3_0>Members are nominated to the court by the president and are confirmed by the Senate<a3_0/>, serving <a4_0>until the age of <b9_0>70<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The judiciary is further divided into circuit and speciality courts, magistrate courts and justices of the peace. <b6_0>The judicial system<b6_0/> is a blend of common law, based on Anglo-American law, and customary law. An informal system of traditional courts still exists <b7_0>within the rural areas of the country<b7_0/>, with trial by ordeal remaining common despite being officially outlawed.
